title: Cauchy–Schwarz inequality
text:
The Cauchy–Schwarz inequality (also called Cauchy–Bunyakovsky–Schwarz inequality) is considered one of the most important and widely used <a href="Inequality%20%28mathematics%29">inequalities</a> in mathematics.
The inequality for sums was published by . The corresponding inequality for integrals was published by and . Schwarz gave the modern proof of the integral version.

Generalizations.
Various generalizations of the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality exist. <a href="H%C3%B6lder%27s%20inequality">Hölder's inequality</a> generalizes it to formula_168 norms. More generally, it can be interpreted as a special case of the definition of the norm of a linear operator on a <a href="Banach%20space">Banach space</a> (Namely, when the space is a <a href="Hilbert%20space">Hilbert space</a>). Further generalizations are in the context of <a href="operator%20theory">operator theory</a>, e.g. for operator-convex functions and <a href="operator%20algebra">operator algebra</a>s, where the domain and/or range are replaced by a <a href="C%2A-algebra">C*-algebra</a> or <a href="W%2A-algebra">W*-algebra</a>.
An inner product can be used to define a <a href="positive%20linear%20functional">positive linear functional</a>.
